 ZAMBIA URBAN RESTRUCTURING AND WATER SUPPLY PROJECT Chapter 1: SECTOR BACKGROUND A Country Background 1.1 Zambia's economy has been in decline since the mid-1970s, as evidenced by Gross Domestic Product (GDP) growth which fell from 3.7 percent per annum in the early 1970s to an average of only 1.1 percent during the 1974-90 period. In response to falling copper prices and deteriorating terms of trade, the Government of the Republic of Zambia (GRZ) during the 1970s and 1980s undertook substantial borrowing to the extent that Zambia's debt is now one of the highest in the world relative to national output and exports. Sporadic attempts at reform during the 1980s foundered, public sector intervention in the economy discouraged private and local initiatives, and by 1990 Zambia was classified as a low income country. 1.2 Over the past four years Zambia has instituted and vigorously pursued an ambitious national program of economic reform. The present government, which came to power in 1991, has dismantled nearly all price and exchange rate controls, eliminated import and export licensing, decontrolled interest rates, lowered and compressed tariff rates and brought inflation down to manageable levels. Comprehensive programs of parastatal privatization and civil service reform have been initiated. While preparing the way for increased private investment, Government has moved to increase efficiency as the primary short term means to boost productivity. However, the success of the reform program overall will depend not only on efficiency improvements, but also on economic diversification and expansion. Infrastructure has a fundamental role to play in creating an enabling environment for such growth and development. 1.3 The ability of GRZ to sustain its sweeping program of reforms will, in Zambia's newly democratic system, depend upon continuing political support engendered by concrete results. The most direct expression of these results will be improvements in living standards, which have been declining in real terms since 1970. Key policy initiatives intended to produce these improvements include rehabilitation and extension of infrastructure and services, devolution of responsibility and authority from central to local government, and reform of distorted land markets and cumbersome delivery systems. Current estimates indicate that annual GDP growth rates of five percent could be attained through higher productivity and increased investment. 1.4 Reform efforts are proceeding throughout all sectors of the Zambian economy. All of these efforts face common constraints: (a) the accumulation over more than two decades of extensive, inappropriate policies and regulations; (b) deteriorating capacity of existing investments to support economic activities; and (c) limited human and financial resources with which to implement new policies, rehabilitate existing systems and extend sustainable services to the majority low income population. Even short term gains in efficiency and productivity in all economic sectors will depend to a significant degree upon successful resolution of these common constraints.
 -2 - B The Urban Context 1.5 Overview. Zambia is the third most highly urbanized country in sub-Saharan Africa. Out of a total of 8.3 million residents (1992 World Bank Atlas), 42 percent or nearly 3.5 million are estimated to live in urban areas. Over 60 percent live along the line of rail which connects Livingstone in the South with Ndola in the northern Copperbelt region. In the 1990 census (the last detailed count taken), Lusaka, the capital and largest city, had a population of 870,000. The key Copperbelt cities of Ndola and Kitwe each had populations of over 400,000. 1.6 During the 1960s and 1970s, the production and export of copper led to the expansion of the urban economy. Zambia experienced high levels of rural-urban migration as Zambians sought to benefit from urban-based employment opportunities and subsidized food and infrastructure. However, the decline in the economy eroded many of the benefits of urban living and the Zambia Poverty Assessment (Report No. 12985-ZA dated November 30, 1994) estimates that up to 40 percent of the urban population currently lives below the poverty line. Although outmigration has not occurred commensurate with urban economic decline, urban growth rates have slowed from a rate of 5.8 percent between 1969 and 1990 to 3.7 percent per annum for the period between 1980 and 1990. Urban growth today is thus a function of natural growth, on the basis of which it can be predicted that there will be more than five million Zambians living in urban areas by the year 2000. 1.7 Two central themes arise from the copper-based development of Zambia's cities. First was the underlying assumption dating back to the colonial period that Zambia should remain essentially rural and that towns should not become a permanent home for the majority of workers. From the outset then, legal tenure and the provision of housing or amenities for non-formal residents were not priorities. In practice, rigid regulations governing land use directed organic growth to informal settlements. Over time these residents have become the majority and currently comprise nearly 60 percent of all city dwellers. Consistent with past policies, this majority has limited or no access to formal sources of potable water, sanitary means of solid and human waste disposal, and basic health and educational services. This in turn makes them prone to environmental health risks such as cholera, typhoid and dysentery. 1.8 Second, in the period after Independence, it was assumed that copper export earnings could support sophisticated infrastructure for those who would be Zambia's permanent urban dwellers. Most of Zambia's urban productive and infrastructure capacity in use today was created during the boom years of 1965-74, is costly to maintain and operate, and restricted to formal business and settlement areas. A consequence of this historical development is that Zambia's cities are now spatially segregated, with dilapidated, often inappropriate infrastructure for which costs are not recovered from consumers. Cost recovery has not been emphasized; for example, even as late as 1979, residents in council housing were consuming 200 liters of water per capita per day without paying for it. Furthermore, urban planning continues to be captured by the regulatory framework of these standards. These themes therefore suggest that the challenge in the urban sector is to reconceptualize the planning and provision of urban infrastructure, to improve incentives for its efficient operation and management, and ensure that all future investments are driven by what consumers want and are willing to pay for, rather than by central planning processes.
 1.9 Urban Infrastructure. The decline of urban services and infrastructure can be directly linked to the decline in productivity of the urban formal sector, which in turn has a reinforcing negative impact on the potential growth of the urban economy. Industrialists for example have cited the lack of basic urban infrastructure as hampering growth, while the demand for extension and rehabilitation of urban services and infrastructure far exceeds available resources. Since 1989 local government capital investments have decreased by almost 80 percent in real terms in the 12 municipalities for which data are available. Where investments have taken place the focus has tended to be on building new infrastructure rather than on rehabilitation and maintenance. Little attention has been given to the sustainability of such investments, and given the cost of the improvements being undertaken, few funds remain for expansion or even maintenance. Furthermore, the strengthening of existing urban infrastructure addresses only a part of the problem. The Zambia Poverty Assessment illustrates the effect on the poor urban majority who, in the face of decreasing wages and employment, must invest more resources in terms of time and money to compensate for the absent or deteriorating services. 1.10 Urban Policy Development. GRZ's primary policy initiative to date in the urban sector has been the devolution of responsibility and authority to local governments. Within months of assuming office in 1991, GRZ passed the Local Government Act (LGA) which substantially increases the administrative and financial autonomy of the country's 22 city and municipal governments. Central government transfers of domestic revenues to local governments have virtually ceased, despite concurrent expenditures on their functions. However, before councils can be held fully responsible, central ministry powers and obligations contained in the LGA need to be changed. For example, the LGA states grants must be provided and thus does not currently reflect the government's intention to eliminate such grants. Other conflicts include central government control over civil service staffing and remuneration at the local level. Nonetheless, while the Ministry of Local Government and Housing (MLGH) retains important and possibly conflicting regulatory functions under the LGA, the main responsibility for planning and implementing urban development now rests with Zambia's local governments. Technical assistance provided as part of the Planning Management and Capital Programming subcomponent will lay the foundation for the development of a comprehensive urban policy and strategy, including changes as needed to the legal and regulatory framework. C Urban Water and Sanitation 1.11 As indicated, at Independence Zambia inherited and initially managed to maintain core urban infrastructure built to high standards. As the country's economy deteriorated, however, maintenance of this infrastructure has been deferred to the point where many urban water and sewerage systems are now on the verge of collapse. This decline in urban services has adversely affected all sectors, including the investment in and development of the private sector that is essential to the growth of the economy. Throughout the country, due to systemic failures, individuals and firms are increasingly forced to provide their own water supply, sanitation and other infrastructure, and to bear the corresponding costs. This represents a significant impediment to the growth and prosperity of these firms, and where they compete with firms that operate in an environment of adequate infrastructure and services, to put them at a competitive disadvantage. 1.12 The impact of the deteriorating urban services has been most severe for the 40 percent of the urban population living in poverty, who bear disproportionate financial and health costs associated with poor water and sanitation. While existing supplies are directed to upper and high income consumers
 - 4 - who do not apparently appear to pay the full cost of the services, lower income residents in informal settlements appear to pay excessively high prices, in terms of cash and time, for informal access to low quality water. Many of theses costs, such as those associated with time spent in water collection and risks to health and personal safety, are predominantly borne by women. Perhaps one of the most devastating impacts of the decay in urban infrastructure, with particular impact on the urban poor, is the steady increase in waterborne diseases. Outbreaks of cholera have been recorded in 11 urban centers in recent years and serious infrastructure maintenance and operational deficiencies have been identified in the 22 cities and towns that comprise virtually the entire urban population of the country. Household surveys in poor areas indicate that the current water supply facilities represent neither what the poor want nor what they are willing to pay for. These same surveys identify potable water supply as the foremost priority for improvement. 1.13 Water Policy Development. While developments in the water sector are representative of a wider array of national policy initiatives affecting the urban sector, efforts to rationalize the policy framework and clarify responsibilities are farther along than in most sub-sectors related to urban infrastructure. To overcome a host of problems, a Programme Coordination Unit (PCU) was established in 1993 with the task of recommending to GRZ how best to reorganize the water supply and sanitation sector. The PCU, which reports to the Permanent Secretary of the Ministry of Energy and Water Development (MEWD), is composed of the MEWD, MLGH, National Commission for Development Planning, Ministry of Health, Ministry of Environment and Natural Resources, Environmental Council of Zambia, National Council of Scientific Research, Ministry of Works and Supply, and Ministry of Agriculture, Food and Fisheries. The specific mandate of the PCU is to: (a) recommend policy reforms; (b) clarify the respective responsibilities of the various actors in the sector; (c) propose an appropriate framework for planning, development, operation and maintenance of the infrastructure in the sector; and (d) determine how best to strengthen, restructure, and/or reform the various institutions with responsibilities for service provision. The PCU is supported by a donor-financed secretariat (financed by NORAD and GTZ), the Water Supply and Sanitation Development Group (WSDG), to provide technical and policy support. 1.14 Early in 1994, Cabinet formally accepted a set of sector principles intended to serve as guidelines in the formulation of proposals for the reorganization of the sector. These include: (a) separation of water resource management from water supply and sanitation; (b) separation of regulatory and executive functions; (c) devolution of authority to local authorities and private enterprises; (d) full cost recovery in the long run; (e) human resource development leading to more effective institutions; (f) use of technology appropriate to local conditions; and (g) increased GRZ priority and budget spending to the sector. 1.15 In December 1994, a Cabinet Memorandum was passed which clarified the organizational structure and respective roles of the different entities involved. Adoption by GRZ of a sector strategy which defines sector restructuring was a condition for second tranche release under the Economic and
 Social Adjustment Credit (ESAC)(Cr.2577-ZA); the condition was met by Cabinet's approval of this memorandum. Key elements of this strategy are as follows: * First, the PCU would be transformed into the National Water and Sanitation Council (NWASCO) answerable to MEWD. This statutory body would be responsible for (i) development of policies and standards; (ii) preparation of strategic plans and investment programs; and (iii) monitoring and regulating water supply and sanitation service delivery and the organizations providing these services. * Second, MLGH would be responsible for all executive functions related to water supply and sanitation. It would assist councils in the performance of their water and sanitation delivery functions in the urban, peri-urban and rural areas. Capital development funds (GRZ and external) for water supply and sanitation would be channeled through the recently established Department of Infrastructure and Support Services (DISS) in MLGH. DISS would facilitate the design, programming and implementation of local authority infrastructure projects, and ensure that local authorities have access to the resources needed to construct and manage critical infrastructure on a sustainable basis. * Third, feasibility studies and pilot programs for establishing commercially oriented water supply and sanitation utilities would be commissioned in the Copperbelt and Northwestern Province to represent urban and rural conditions, with the former to be supported under this project (para 2.16). D Bank Experience in the Urban and Water Supply Sectors 1.16 Bank experience in both the urban and water sectors in Zambia has been limited. Bank experience in the urban sector is restricted to the Lusaka Squatter Upgrading and Site and Services Project (Ln. 1057-ZA) which was approved in late 1974 and completed at the end of 1981. This project was one of the Bank's first urban initiatives in Africa, and was implemented during a period of economic difficulty in Zambia, as copper prices dropped 40 percent in the midst of the international oil crisis and escalating regional conflicts. Nevertheless, the Lusaka project met its physical development objectives and established a system of community participation that, while no longer current today, was a model in the urban development field for that era. 1.17 The Lusaka project eventually provided more than 30,000 new and improved homesites (communal water supply facilities, etc.) in the informal settlements of the capital city and established a significant cadre of Zambian professionals with expertise in low-cost housing, many of whom remain in government employment. The project did not, however, achieve financially sustainable operations and associated institutional reforms were not fully realized. Among the lessons learned, positive and negative, are the following. First, the presence of a relatively large concentration of houses replete with basic infrastructure in Lusaka led to the emergence of economic activities in the informal sector. Further, as was highlighted in the Zambia Poverty Assessment, the granting of legal status to participating compounds in the project enabled them to become centers of economic activity which persist today. The significance of regularizing land tenure is thus a critical lesson learned from the Lusaka project. Second, the delivery of public services failed for a variety of reasons, but most fundamentally because:
 (i) water supply service levels were not based on what residents wanted; (ii) technical norms were often unrealistic; (iii) community organizations were expected to operate and maintain facilities even though they were not consulted during planning and implementation; (iv) cost recovery was through a consolidated service charge for water, without an effective system of sanctions against defaulters, other than to cut water supply at communal taps (one for 25 houses); and (v) apathy of city council officials, due in part to confusion over who was responsible, exacerbated low cost recovery. 1.18 Bank experience in the water and sanitation sector in Zambia is equally sparse. In this sector, the Rural Water Supply Project Credit (Cr. 1362-ZA) was intended to provide piped water to 29,000 people in four main towns and point system water supply to an additional 110,000 people in six rural districts in Northern Zambia through the construction of wells and boreholes. The physical objectives of the project were largely met, although implementation was hampered by IDA's suspension of disbursements to Zambia from 1987-91. The project was deemed unsuccessful and unsustainable, largely because GRZ failed to impose the financial control systems and tariff increases necessary to cover operating and maintenance costs. Individual districts had little incentive to improve their revenue collection because all revenues were credited to central government. A positive outcome, not part of the project, was that the project enabled IDA to assist in the initial GTZ-funded institutional study for reorganization of the water sector which has led to the policies currently being introduced by GRZ. 1.19 Although not directly a part of Bank projects, several innovations in intermediate sewerage technologies were attempted in the 1950s and 1960s in the Zambian cities. Sewered aquaprivies were established in low income council housing on the premise that residents consuming less water could be serviced by lower cost low volume wastewater disposal systems. However, a World Bank review of these technologies in 1978 indicated that as there was no check on water consumption (owing to a lack of enforcement of tariffs), water consumption was excessive, which completely destroyed the validity of the "intermediate" solutions. Seventeen years later these houses have virtually no water supply because the public water supply system has almost collapsed, and most residents have reverted to primitive pit latrines. 1.20 With the benefit of hindsight, and experience from the Lusaka project, the following lessons can be learned. First, the underlying assumption that "appropriate technology" could be delivered through existing operationally inefficient institutions did not hold up to experience. Second, the presumption that the poor would be satisfied with a centrally determined level of service proved incorrect. The poor, in fact, were investing time and cash to acquire privately provided water, and had definite preferences as to service levels and willingness to pay. Third, experiences from diverse countries suggest that under suitable incentive structures, community-based organizations in low income areas are often more successful in tackling local operational problems, such as system breakdowns, and recovering operation and maintenance costs, when compared to large water and sanitation utilities.
 E Strategy and Approach to the Sector 1.21 The objective of the Bank's country assistance strategy (last discussed in conjunction with the Economic and Social Adjustment Credit (Cr. 2577-ZA), dated March 1994) is to assist GRZ in its efforts to achieve sustainable economic growth and thereby reduce poverty. Although the broad-based reforms adopted by GRZ have been both courageous and significant (para 1.2), the reforms have been insufficient to secure the level and nature of supply response required to achieve the overriding goal of decreasing poverty. To assist GRZ, the Bank's overall strategy for FY96-98 is to encourage sustainable economic growth by continuing to support macroeconomic stabilization and structural reform policies, promoting further private sector development and greater public sector efficiency, and increasing direct assistance to the poor and vulnerable groups. With respect to infrastructure, key elements of this strategy are to: (a) improve the enabling environment for private sector growth through investments in infrastructure and human resources; (b) decentralize and restructure the delivery of infrastructure and services to enhance efficiency and sustainability; and (c) remove subsidies and encourage private sector participation in the provision of public services. This project would help to remove constraints to economic growth and diversification by addressing issues of public service reform with particular emphasis on devolution of responsibility to local levels, adoption of demand-based approaches to infrastructure planning and implementation, improvements to revenue generation and cost recovery for municipal services overall, and development of human resources. 1.22 Strategic objectives of the project include creation of commercially-oriented water and sanitation utilities, near term improvements in critical urban infrastructure and services with particular emphasis upon laying the groundwork for service improvements to the largely unserved urban majority, in concert with the institutional and policy reforms necessary for equitable and sustainable sectoral growth in the medium term. Water supply and sanitation have been accorded the highest priority for near term rehabilitation, on the one hand because of direct links to health and productivity, the extent of the population currently unserved, and the significant fixed investments currently in danger of collapse; and on the other because of the progress already made in legislative reform and on the policy agenda. Lessons learned from efforts in water supply and sanitation to encourage greater use of commercial practices, foster accountability of service providers to service consumers, and manage infrastructure at the lowest appropriate level, will in turn be used to shape the medium-term approach to the provision of urban infrastructure and services overall. 1.23 To achieve these overall objectives, the Urban Restructuring and Water Supply Project (URWSP) aims particularly to assist the participating urban local authorities to: (a) efficiently and equitably manage existing infrastructure and services, based on what residents want and are willing to pay for;
 - 8 - (b) provide incentives for employees and organizations responsible for operations and maintenance of urban services to work in accordance with transparent and consistent performance criteria; (c) foster accountability of civic planners and service providers by ensuring that key decisions on service level choices are made at the lowest appropriate level; and (d) test out institutional processes through which future investment programs represent value for money for all service users in urban towns, and are effective in checking urban environmental deterioration. 1.24 Consistent with this phased approach, it will be important that planning and policy-related decisions await the completion of the relevant project investigations. Thus each participating local council will be required to agree, as part of the subsidiary legal agreement, that they will protect dwellings and structures within community compounds and informal settlements from demolition, unless this demolition is required to provide essential urban services. However, such demolition would be subject to prior review by IDA and must be conducted in line with IDA resettlement policies. Under the Planning, Management and Capital Programming technical assistance, the "as built" plans of each council will be reviewed, particularly as they have deviated or invalidated structure plans, sectoral master plans, and existing provisions of the Town and Country Planning Act. Findings will be discussed with all parties, and development plans, zoning ordinances and other related regulations will be revised accordingly. 1.25 Once the medium-term framework is in place, a follow-on project is envisioned that would extend the lessons learned in water supply and sanitation to the provision of urban infrastructure and services overall. F Rationale for IDA Involvement 1.26 The range and complexity of problems facing urban areas clearly point to the need for integrated and appropriate urban and water policy frameworks that would not only guide the transition from subsidized infrastructure and devolution of service delivery from the central government to local entities, but also address appropriate directions for the medium and longer term. Given the fragmentation of efforts to date, IDA is well placed to assist GRZ in the development of an integrated approach involving the establishment of an appropriate policy framework, rehabilitation of essential urban services, and improvements in urban efficiency as well as managerial and financial capacity. IDA's involvement in a range of related sectors (roads, health services, education, poverty alleviation) would be key in playing this integrating role. The project further builds upon and facilitates implementation of the overall policy framework for water supply and sanitation, the development of which was supported by the last adjustment credit (para 1.15). By beginning to address the needs of urban residents who currently fall outside the formal structure, the project would also help to improve the level and sustainability of services to the poor.
 9- G Related Donor Activities 1.27 As noted previously, the German aid agency GTZ and the Norwegian aid agency NORAD have had long-standing relationships in the water sector in Zambia (para 1.13); they are particularly active at the level of MEWD in providing technical support as part of the Secretariat. They and several donors have been or are involved at the local and/or community level, including UNCHS, JICA and Irish Aid. There have also been a number of NGO initiatives in the water sector, among them World Vision and Catholic Charities. The donor community has been less involved in the urban sector. The British aid agency, ODA, has just begun an large-scale initiative with MLGH aimed at improving the accounting and financial skills at the local government level with the Local Government Support Project (LOGOS). The proposed IDA credit has been designed to complement and build upon the ongoing donor support being provided in the water and urban sectors in Zambia.
 - 10- Chapter 2: THE PROJECT A Project Origin and Formulation 2.1 The virtual cessation of subsidies which followed the 1991 revision of the Local Government Act (LGA) (para 1.10) left Zambia's local councils -- already incapable of providing basic services to their informally settled, low income majority populations -- unable to prevent the rapid deterioration of existing urban infrastructure. Outbreaks in urban areas of cholera and other infectious diseases related to inadequate safe water supply prompted GRZ, in late 1993, to request IDA assistance to effect short- term rehabilitation of critical urban water and sanitation systems, and delineate more extensive reforms required to promote equity and local self sufficiency in infrastructure and service provision, maintenance and operations. 2.2 The project has been formulated in light of GRZ's broader reform objectives including poverty alleviation, decentralization of authority and responsibility, encouragement of private sector and local initiatives, and promotion of efficient sectoral economic performance. The project's design explicitly recognizes the immediate need to address critical water and sanitation system rehabilitation requirements while initiating the longer term reform processes, without which broader investments in urban infrastructure and services would be unsustainable. With respect to long-term water supply development, appropriate consultations have been held with the WSDG, the PCU support unit. Project design has been guided by extensive consultation with stakeholders, including results from the Bank- supported Zambia Poverty Assessment and follow-up interviews with residents in peri-urban areas. Formal consultation with MLGH and all local councils, including both elected and appointed officials, proposed for participation in the project has been achieved through a series of workshops and participatory exercises at the community level. This process will continue throughout project implementation and phased infrastructure design and investments will be tied to informed, representative decisions achieved over time through broad consultation. 2.3 Formulation of the project has emphasized development of capacity within existing ministerial, council and community structures. Overall project supervision will be achieved through DISS in MLGH (para 1.15), with the 10 participating councils and their constituent communities playing the key roles in formulating the designs and reforms necessary to sustain local investments. In order to achieve efficient utilization of resources, the proposed project would be implemented in close coordination with two streams of relevant donor-financed urban and water supply sectoral efforts. The former includes the LOGOS Project within MLGH, which seeks to strengthen the local government capacity and thereby facilitate the devolution of responsibility to the local councils, both urban and rural; initial activities focus on local government finance, performance appraisal and participatory planning (para 1.27). The latter includes GTZ and NORAD support to the PCU and its technical arm the WSDG, first to devise and subsequently implement an integrated water sector policy and program (paras 1.13-1.15).

PROJECT BACKGROUND Urban Poverty: Access to Water and Sanitation Services 2. One quarter of the entire Zambian population resides in low income urban areas where the majority live below the poverty line [Zambia Urban Poverty Assessment, 1994]. The urban poor have severe problems with access to water and sanitation services as existing piped water supplies are directed to upper income consumers. Legal low income areas are officially provided with standpipes (1/25 households). However, field visits show that many standpipes are no longer in operation, and those that do still function frequently only have water for only a few hours a day. 3. From the perspective of the urban poor two issues are clear. These costs are predominantly born by women. Second, there appears to be little sense of community ownership. Public facilities have high breakdown rates and are frequently vandalized because services are not organized through a sustainable system of incentives. 4. In recognition of the above and that the needs of low income urban residents will not be addressed by rehabilitation of formal infrastructure, the URWSP has a "demonstration" component to address the specific needs of low income populations in the short run, while building the institutional mechanisms central to more equitably planned infrastructure in the future. The experience of large scale "squatter" upgrading in Lusaka during the 1970s is perhaps the best documented. The Lusaka Squatter Upgrading and Sites and Services Project (Loan 1057- ZA), a model of its time, included the provision of water and sanitation infrastructure. Between 1975 and 1980, 20,000 plots were provided with basic services, a considerable achievement. As early as 1978, however, difficulties with operations and maintenance were apparent; services could not be sustained and the problems experienced provide important lessons for future work in the sector. 6. A review of the literature reveals the following key problem areas: (a) Dissatisfaction with the pre-determined level of service Initial project planning was driven by engineers who determined basic service levels (one standpipe with two taps per 25 households). Those in the overspill area, whose higher mean incomes resulted in a preference for yard taps and house connections, were ignored. (b) Limited role of community participation Participation was seen as a means to facilitate speedy project implementation. Community development activities were thus driven by the engineering component. Participation was essentially a briefing process, limiting the scope for questioning and active resident involvement. (c) Failure of the project to develop sustainable rules for cost recovery There was an assumption that groups of households residing around public standposts could "mutually police" cost recovery. Operations and maintenance were often not specifically considered in project design. (d) Perceived unfairness ofpricing rules by community members A flat rate of K1 was charged initially and later raised to K3. Residents complained about the charge for a number of reasons: some services such as refuse collection were included in the consolidated charge but never provided, some consumers considered the level of service inadequate, and for the poorest residents, the charge appeared discriminatory. (e) Failure of the city council to implement incentives for prompt payment No incentives were established under the project for residents to pay promptly. In some cases those who had paid were affected by disconnections, a council response to high levels of non- payment within communities. (f) Lack of attention to institutional arrangements There was an assumption that appropriate technology could be delivered through existing (inappropriate) institutions. In particular no attention was given to linkages among the communities, the project, and the councils who were expected to manage the project after a rapid hand-over by project staff.

III. PROJECT DESIGN AND PRINCIPLES Demonstration Project Model II. Preparation of the demonstration component has focused on understanding the history of urban upgrading, learning from existing experiences and in turn testing the validity of hypotheses at the community level using PRA methods in a process of systematic client consultation. Two broad conclusions have shaped the demonstration model: (i) it is important that project arrangements are sufficiently flexible to allow for differentiated levels of service delivery should this be "demanded" by the community; and (ii) it is important that the full community participate in the design of the project and the supporting institutional arrangements. 12. Agreed Principles of Project Design (i) projects must be community generated; communities themselves must play the central role in the design, implementation, monitoring and management of the project (ii) projects must be within the technical, financial and managerial capacity of communities; these capacities will vary among communities, but an economic test based on demand considerations, is expected to play a screening role and result in a wide range of technologies and projects. (iii) municipal partners must have access to technical assistance to enable them to respond to processes at the community level; sustainability of the project approach hinges on this principle and the project recognizes the key institutional support through UNCHS and LOGOS projects undertaken within councils. (iv) municipal partners should participate fully in the design of institutional procedures and definition of the council's role; councils should only be expected to provide what is reasonable within resource levels. In keeping with the policy of decentralization, project activities should be delegated to the lowest possible level (within communities where possible). Agreed Criteria for Project Participation 13. Budget evidence suggests that municipalities' real expenditures on urban services (as distinct from administration) have mostly declined substantially in recent years on both recurrent and capital investment accounts. Municipalities acknowledge that expenditures on staff have been excessive in terms of their proportions of overall totals, and have embarked on ambitious establishment reduction programs. Representative domestic rates bills suggest that, in some municipalities at least, they may now approach affordability limits for a significant proportion of ratepayers. In view of the timing their approval amounts merely to a retrospective endorsement of changes which have already taken place - often, on the expenditure side, mainly reflecting the actions of officials. Normal uncertainty in budget-making is greatly compounded in Zambia' s case by the poor economic climate, high level of inflation, and unpredictably of central government decisions on matters such as global pay increases and payment of grants. Budgeting procedures need to be able to cope accordingly. One approach is to incorporate in budgets substantial reserves for contingencies, with proper political level approval procedures governing their use. The alternative is to make regular supplementary budgets to effect adjustments; or, as is the case in some countries, to enact budgets covering a shorter period than a year. However, either of the latter are not practicable without fundamental improvements in the efficiency of current budgeting systems to shorten preparation periods. A change from accruals to cash, or cash and expenditure commitments, as the basis for budgeting and accounting would further serve the interests of greater certainty in planning and managing the allocation of resources. 26. Medium Term Financial Planning. Neither for capital nor for recurrent expenditure do municipal governments presently draw up indicative medium term financial plans. Such plans can provide a valuable discipline forcing proper evaluation of the longer term financial implications of current decisions, including identification of potential shortfalls in revenues and options for correcting them. Arguably, their introduction is not practicable until economic conditions improve and stabilize; but work could begin now on developing a framework for later implementation when feasible.

Regulations require that every commitment to expenditure incurred by a spending department must secure the prior authorization of the finance department. Such authorization should be given by reference to budget votes; but in practice decisions appear to be taken rather according to the municipality's cash position, and views on the degree of urgency or priority - confirming the ineffectiveness of the current budgets. In two of the municipalities visited, the expenditure control system appeared virtually to have broken down. Spending departments were incurring commitments on their own, subsequently presenting invoices for payment, usually successfully. 28. Receivables and Payables. Although those visited could not provide comprehensive statements, municipalities everywhere are thought to have large outstanding amounts currently receivable and payable (debtors and creditors). Prompt recognition and settlement of inter-governmental obligations is just as important as for any other. Failure to take them seriously on either side is likely to sour mutual relationships and engender indisciplined "tit-for-tat" approaches to mutual debt problem resolution. These reports are frequently submitted late, often by several months, owing to delays in computer processing of the accounting records. They are compiled manually from computer printouts or alternative sources. The expenditure report formats are of little use for the purposes of meaningful financial control: expenditure is not cumulated for the year; no comparison is given with budget provisions; and no analysis is given according to service or spending department. The income report formats are better, giving both cumulative figures and comparisons with budgetary estimates for principal sources; but they give insufficient detail, do not follow the same format as that of the budget, and sometimes mix accounting transactions with true receipts figures. No regular statements of the municipality cash position in total or by fund account are provided. 30. Bookkeeping and Accounts. Until recently the municipalities had not prepared final accounts since the mid-1980s. Three have now engaged consultants to prepare them up to date, while the fourth is undertaking the work itself. The exercise is hardly meaningful, however, since many records appear to have gone missing. Like that of the budget, the format of the final accounts presentation is so uninformative as to be almost meaningless. There are no comparisons with budget provisions, no capital accounts, no sensible summaries, and no explanations of balance sheet items. 31. Three of the municipalities visited maintain all billings, personal ledger, payroll and expenditure and income records on mainframe computers. They seemed wedded to the mainframe concept, and unfamiliar with the power, potential flexibility and relative cheapness of modem PC-based networked systems. Municipalities considering systems computerization or upgrades clearly need access to independent expert advice. In two cases (Lusaka and Ndola) the systems, both employing very old technology, were found to be on the verge of total collapse. Urgent replacement is required in each case with modern networked on-line systems, software and printers. It is proposed to include this as a component of the UWSP.

The divisions seem often to be understaffed, and the impression gained was that they spend much of their time on the routine checking of transactions within the finance department. Internal Audit should be a service to the whole municipality, charged with the seeking out, not only of malpractice, but also of waste and inefficiency. 33. Effective internal auditors need specialist training. Means of providing an appropriate training facility, to develop a cadre of such expertise, need to be explored. 34. The placing of the local government internal audit service within the finance department deserves to be reviewed. In some other countries the independent status and high ranking of this service is emphasized by making it responsible to the town clerk or equivalent top official, or even directly to the elected Council. Financial Systems Reform 35. There is an evident need for a full scale reform of the municipalities' entire financial systems and procedures to bring them up to modern standards and to achieve effective internal financial control and accountability. The reform must start from fundamentals, that is, review of the governing financial regulations, and then proceed to cover the accounting framework, raising and recording of income, authorization of expenditure, payment systems, budgetary procedures and format, financial reporting procedures and formats, format of final accounts, a framework for the adoption of medium term financial planning, and computerization principles and recommended configurations. Rather than rigid prescription of details, the reform should establish principles accompanied by guidance giving models for municipalities to adapt to their particular needs. Supporting model software would be designed, running on networked systems, to support all transactions, accounting and reporting procedures. Additionally a budgeting module would be developed to allow rapid assembly of information, scenario testing, and expeditious production of budget documents. A major consultancy effort would be needed. Development would need to be carried out in a volunteer municipality, and frequent consultation held with other municipalities to ensure that the systems could adapt to varying detailed local requirements. Consultation would be needed with other donors who may be addressing similar areas before the precise shape of this assistance could be finalized. Training Needs of Finance Staff 36. The Urban Restructuring and Water Supply Project will build institutional, financial and technical capacity in the project areas so that future urban investment programs are built through a decentralized, demand-driven planning process. The project's immediate investment focus on water supply and sanitation infrastructure is not only because water and wastewater deficiencies are recognized as among the most severe service problems, but also because this 'single-sectoral' investment program enables the project to test out what works and what doesn't work in institutional and financial arrangements before a wider multi-sectoral demand-driven approach can be operationalized beyond this point. 2. The Monitoring and Evaluation system, therefore, can be viewed in terms of two aspects: * A 'doing and learning' process via water and sanitation initiatives taken under the Rehabilitation and Demonstration components, in which the quality of technical assistance and investment progress will be monitored and tracked; * Building up a cost-effective process of collecting information, consulting with stakeholders (representatives of GRZ, Councils, commerce and industries and urban residents), training, and technical assistance. This could help design future urban investments that are (a) responsive to user needs, and (b) efficient in the operations and maintenance of existing assets as well as in the selection of new investments. 3. The project expects to incorporate the lessons learned from each stage of implementation in the subsequent phases of the project cycle. In other words, the program of investments and technical assistance will depend on the quality of the Monitoring and Evaluation system. 4. Types of Information to be Collected and Data Gathering Responsibilities. The Monitoring and Evaluation (M&E) system has two distinct aspects. The first relates to tracking quantitative information showing financial and physical progress in achieving project milestones. The second relates to qualitative or process aspects, the object of which being to review the quality of project implementation, so that there is an opportunity to change or modify the succeeding year's program design. The latter depends on the extent to which information gathered enables GRZ and the International Development Association understand what appears to be working and what isn't during the course of project implementation in each of the project towns.

OVERVIEW The appraisal follow-up mission conducted an environmental analysis, and came to the conclusion that the overall environmental impact of project investments will be positive. Negative impacts could be adequately mitigated and managed during project design and implementation. Environmental concerns are being addressed in all three components of the project: * While implementing the emergency phase measures, as an essential component of design and construction contracts; * While implementing the Demonstration component, through the consultative processes in which pern-urban communities define their local environmental priorities, and * Through the process of participatory planning recommended under the Capacity Building component of the project. Some of the principal environmental issues, and how the project proposes to deal with them are discussed below. A. Environmental issues in the Emergency Phase measures Issue 1: Increase in water supply will improve access to clean water for communities, and thereby have an overall benefit. Issue 5: The local environmental impacts of additional wastewater generated The project will support investments for the emergency rehabilitation of wastewater conveyance infrastructure. In addition, studies are proposed to review and evaluate: - Past investments in conveyance and collection systems in the copperbelt towns and Lusaka, and - Feasible sanitation solutions for built-up areas that are served with house connections/yard taps and inadequate wastewater and sewage disposal arrangements (notably Council-owned housing in Copperbelt towns). Issue 6: The environmental impact of additional wastewater on natural resources The project is supporting investments designed to rehabilitate sewage treatment facilities in order to mitigate negative impacts of wastewater on natural resources. The question of re- using treated wastewater for peri-urban farming and pisciculture will also be evaluated. Issue 7: Kafue River Basin Water Resource Management Much of the project investments are taking place in the industrial and commercial zones along Kafue river. A component has been included to prepare and introduce a water resource management and environmental monitoring program for the Kafue River Basin. This component is consistent with the project objectives in the towns located within the river basin. The Environmental Council of Zambia has prepared a Kafue River Basin Environmental Monitoring Program, which it has not been able to implement due to lack of funds. doc.repnme: Zambia - Urban Restructuring and Water Supply Project
doc.abstracts: The objectives of the Urban Restructuring and Water Supply Project are: 1) provide immediate solutions to the most severe water and sewerage infrastructure deficiencies in nine key urban areas; 2) test out community-generated and managed water and sanitation demonstration projects which meet articulated needs at an affordable price while strengthening local councils capacities to support community based initiatives in Lusaka and the participating Copperbelt councils; and 3) initiate broader institutional and financial reforms required for providing organizational incentives for investing in, operating and maintaining infrastructure based on residents' perceived needs and willingness to pay. Based on priority attached to the water sector expressed in various fora by central and local government and by residents themselves, the project proposes to use water supply as an entry point for developing furture investment programs, initially concentrating on rehabilitation, in formal settlement areas and testing institutional options in peri-urban, unserviced areas. Both activities focus on a participatory demand-based approach, and as such, seek to break the persistent cycle of non-payment and inadequate service provision. Second, technical assistance and studies will be provided to support immediate improvements in participating council's management capacity and propose alternative methods of organizing services and evaluating trade-offs. Third, capacity building assistance will look to the medium term and outline how future urban policy can avoid mistakes of past policies. Project components comprise the following: 1) water supply and sanitation system rehabilitation; 2) community-based water and sanitation demonstration projects; and 3) sectoral and local government reform and capacity building.
